physworld.h

00001 #ifndef _physworld_h
00002 #define _physworld_h
00003 
00004 /**
00005  @mainpage Physgame
00006  The Physgame engine is an abstraction layer between less portable, less user friendly, more sophistciated
00007  libraries and the game you want to make. If we do our jobs right this will save time and effort porting
00008  games between a variety of platforms. If you link only against this library, not a single line of your
00009  Standard compliant C++ code should need to change between platforms. At this early stage we are proving the
00010  concept with "Catch!" our first sample game. It Currently runs on Linux and Windows with an Identical
00011  codebase, when we are done with "Catch!" We want it to have one codebase, and downloadable in the Iphone
00012  app store, the Xbox store, on the PS3, on Steam, and in a variety of linux repositories.
00013 
00014  To get the latest news on development checkout: http://gitorious.org/physgame
00015  The wiki Which acts as our current Knowledge base: http://gitorious.org/physgame/pages/Home
00016 
00017  @section Engine Structure
00018   @subpage MainLoop "Main Loop Flow"
00019 
00020   @subpage CallbackManager "Call Back Manager"
00021 
00022   @subpage EventManager "Event Manager"
00023 
00024   @subpage Actor "Items in the world - Actor Class"
00025 
00026  */
00027

00071 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00072 /// @class PhysWorld
00073 /// @headerfile physworld.h
00074 /// @brief This is the main entry point for the entire library.
00075 /// The physworld coordinates and integrates all the underlying subsystems,
00076 /// Currently Ogre3d is used for 3d Graphics, Bullet is used for physics, and
00077 /// SDL is used for user input and window management. Games will need a
00078 /// container for all the playing pieces. It makes sense to tie all of this
00079 /// functionality into one world object.
00080 ///////////////////////////////////////
00081 class PhysWorld
00082 {
00083         private:
00084                 //Physics Items
00085                 PhysVector3* GeographyLowerBounds;
00086                 PhysVector3* GeographyUpperbounds;
00087                 unsigned short int  MaxPhysicsProxies;
00088 
00089                 btAxisSweep3* BulletBroadphase;
00090                 btDefaultCollisionConfiguration* BulletCollisionConfiguration;
00091                 btCollisionDispatcher* BulletDispatcher;
00092                 btSequentialImpulseConstraintSolver* BulletSolver;
00093                 btSoftRigidDynamicsWorld* BulletDynamicsWorld;
00094 
00095                 //SDL Objects
00096                 SDL_Surface *SDLscreen;
00097 
00098                 //Ogre objects
00099         Ogre::Root* OgreRoot;
00100         Ogre::RenderSystem* OgreRenderSystem;
00101         Ogre::RenderWindow* OgreGameWindow;
00102         Ogre::ResourceGroupManager* OgreResource;
00103                 Ogre::SceneManager* OgreSceneManager;
00104                 Ogre::Camera* OgreCamera;
00105                 Ogre::Viewport* OgreViewport;
00106 
00107                 //Players settings
00108                 Settings* PlayerSettings;
00109 
00110                 //Try to retrieve ogre settinss
00111                 void LoadOgreSettings();
00112 
00113                 //Manages the windows all the graphics will be drawn to
00114                 void CreateRenderWindow();
00115                 void DestroyRenderWindow();
00116 
00117                 //Used by the constructors
00118                 void Construct(PhysVector3* GeographyLowerBounds, PhysVector3* GeographyUpperbounds, unsigned short int MaxPhysicsProxies);
00119         void TestLogger();
00120         template <class T> void OneLogTest(T Data, string DataType,string Message1 = "Logging and Throwing a ", string Message2 = "Logging a ");
00121 
00122                 //SDL specific Items
00123                 //This function will get all the events from SDL and Sort them into one of two Queues
00124                 void PreProcessSDLEvents();
00125         queue<RawEvent*> SDL_WmEvents;
00126         queue<RawEvent*> SDL_UserInputEvents;
00127 
00128         /// Do Not Use this, This should be treated as an internal function, it is \b subject \b to \b change \b without \b warning and could be \b harmful to overall stability if used incorrectly
00129         /// @warning This should be treated as an internal function, it is \b subject \b to \b change \b without \b warning and could be \b harmful to overall stability if used incorrectly
00130         friend void RenderPhysWorld(PhysWorld *TheWorld);
00131 
00132         public:
00133         /// @brief Descriptive constructor
00134         /// This constructor allows for an easier way to define the boundaries for items moving about inside the physworld.
00135         /// @param GeographyLowerBounds The lower limits for the size of the physics simulation
00136         /// @param GeographyUpperbounds The Upper limits for the size of the physics simulation
00137         /// @param MaxPhysicsProxies This is the amount of Adows (Also called Actors or Proxies) allowed in a physics simulation.
00138                 PhysWorld(PhysVector3* GeographyLowerBounds, PhysVector3* GeographyUpperbounds, unsigned short int MaxPhysicsProxies=1024);
00139 
00140         /// @brief Default constructor
00141         /// This simply performs the same work as the descriptive constructor with some sane, but small, limits. It will give you a world which expands for 100 units from the Origin, and only allows 10 Adows.
00142                 PhysWorld();
00143 
00144         /// @brief Deconstructor
00145         /// This Tears down all the items create by the physworld, and safely frees any graphical resources, we will also delete any Objects passed into the
00146         /// Physworld by pointer. We will not delete any pointers we pass out (like from the Events from the Event manager)
00147                 ~PhysWorld();
00148 
00149                 /// @brief Runtime Event logging Function
00150                 /// @param Message This is what will be streamed to the log
00151                 /// Be careful with this function, even though it appears to be a template, it does not support every data type. If Physgame is
00152                 /// Compiled as a Shared Object, Dynamic Linked Library, or some other kind of stand alone library It will only support data types
00153                 /// that are called internally, Currently that list includes: string, char, short int, int, long int, unsigned short int, unsigned int
00154                 /// unsigned long int, bool, float, double, long double, wchar_t, size_t, PhysReal, PhysWhole, PhysString, and PhysVector3. If
00155                 /// compiled statically it should support any data type which supports output streams.
00156         template <class T> void Log(T Message);
00157         /// @brief This is the preffered way to throw an exception currently
00158         /// @param Message This will be streamed to the log, then used in a thrown exception.
00159         /// This will log the Message, and will throw an exception with the Message included. Currently this supports all the Data
00160         /// type the Log function supports
00161         template <class T> void LogAndThrow(T Message);
00162 
00163         /// @brief This Shows an Engine Generated Configuration Screen
00164         /// This could look like and could offer just about any option to the user. It is loosely expected to show Graphical Configuration
00165         /// options, like Vsync and Resolution, But it might ask some really silly stuff. I thnk this would be fine for smaller simpler
00166         /// Which have no other way to configure such things, but any sizable project should develop their own way to expose and manage
00167         /// user settings.
00168         bool ShowSystemSettingDialog();
00169 
00170                 /// @brief This moves the camera relative to the world
00171                 /// @param Position Where should the camera be seated
00172                 /// @param LookAt Point the camera such that this poin is centered on the screen
00173                 /// The parameters really do explain it. This puts the camera at an arbitrary point, pointing at an arbitrary point.
00174                 void MoveCamera(PhysVector3 Position, PhysVector3 LookAt);
00175 
00176         /// @brief This creates the game window and starts the game.
00177         /// Prior to this all of the physics and graphical object containers should have been loaded and prepared for use. There should be
00178         /// minimal delay from the time you call this and the game actually begins.
00179         /// This is also where the Main Loop for the game is housed.
00180         void GameInit();
00181 
00182         /// @brief Performs all the items that would normally be performed during the game loop
00183         /// This simply calls: DoMainLoopPhysics, DoMainLoopInputBuffering, DoMainLoopWindowManagerBuffering, DoMainLoopRender. This is
00184         /// useful for anyone wants to use as little of the existing main loop structure as possible, or does not want to run a certain Items
00185         /// each iteration of the main loop.
00186         void DoMainLoopAllItems();
00187 
00188         /// @brief Increments physics by one step
00189         /// Currently one step is about 1/60 of a second. This function is automatically called in the main loop if a Pre-Physics Callback is
00190         /// set. This is the second step in the main loop chain of events. This is where we expect the majority of our colision events to come
00191         /// from although it is concievable that a game could manually insert those manually.
00192 
00193         void DoMainLoopPhysics();
00194                 void DoMainLoopInputBuffering();
00195                 void DoMainLoopWindowManagerBuffering();
00196                 void DoMainLoopRender();
00197 
00198         void AddActor(ActorBase* ActorToAdd);
00199 
00200 
00201                 //used to set callback functions to be run in the main loop
00202                 PhysWorldCallBackManager* CallBacks;
00203 
00204                 //This will be used to communicate with underlying sybsystems in a clean way
00205                 PhysEventManager*  Events;
00206 };
00207 #endif
